data.title: MonoGame UWP on XBox One Fixes

milestone.title: 3.6 Release
milestone.description: More unit tests, running unit tests on Mac and Linux, SDL2 replacing OpenTK.

data.body:
I ran into a few issues porting a quick test to Xbox One under UWP.

 https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JWzwNUGr9Tk
- It doesn't want to create a 1920x1080 back buffer....  it is like 1832x1023 or something weird.
- There is a thick white border around the display area... might be why I am not getting a 1080p back buffer.
- For some reason XB1 doesn't like how our static VBs and IBs are created... it fails to copy data into them, however dynamic buffers work fine.

The first two i'm told are new features that MS added to make apps seamlessly work on TVs within the safe area.   There are APIs to disable these things which I think we would want to do at the platform level...  games deal with the safe area on their own.

The last one i'm still trying to figure out.  We don't have issues with static VBs or IBs on any other UWP platform...  Windows 10, Windows 10 Mobile, or even Rasberry Pi 2/3.  So either we're doing something wrong that all the other platforms are tolerant of and let slip by...  or the XB1 Win10 OS has a bug in this area.

data.title: SoundEffect.Play throws NullReferenceException when loading raw wav.

milestone.title: 3.6 Release
milestone.description: More unit tests, running unit tests on Mac and Linux, SDL2 replacing OpenTK.

data.body:
Using a DesktopGL project in MonoGame 3.5.0.

Tested with SoundEffect.FromStream and Content.Load and both crash.

[Here ](http://www.hernblog.com/SoundBug.zip)is an example project demonstrating the issue.  Press Z or X to play a sound.

The game crashes because the SoundEffect.SoundBuffer (in SoundEffect.OpenAL.cs) is not set
Theres only one assignment anywhere and it's in SoundEffect.PlatformInitialize but this is only ever called from one of the two SoundEffect constructors. The other constructor is empty and thats the one that gets called when you load the sound effect.

Without having any real understanding of the code path I copied the lines:

```
    SoundBuffer = new OALSoundBuffer();
    SoundBuffer.BindDataBuffer(_data, Format, Size, (int)Rate);
```

into SoundEffect.PlatformLoadAudioStream (in SoundEffect.OpenAL.cs) and it seems to have solved the issue. It would be great if someone who has some knowledge of the system could take a look at this and determine the optimal way of fixing this for the official branch (if it hasn't already been fixed).

This most probably also affects projects packaged with Xamarin.

data.title: Generate PCL Assemblies using Piranha
data.body:
We want to generate the following PCL assemblies for MonoGame:
- MonoGame.Framework.Portable
- MonoGame.Framework.Content.Pipeline.Portable

This involves the following tasks:
- Add the latest [Piranha](https://github.com/Ark-kun/Piranha) executable to the dependencies submodule.
- Modify the [default.build](https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/blob/develop/default.build) script to generate the PCL assemblies.
- Add NuGet packages for each.
- Add the new PCL assemblies to the Windows/Mac/Linux installers.

As long as the new PCL assemblies are placed into the `MonoGame.Framework\bin\Portable` and `MonoGame.Framework.Content.Pipeline\bin\Portable` folders the build server will automatically gather it into the build artifacts and copy them around for the various build steps.

data.title: Implement FrameworkDispatcher
data.body:
Fixes #1494. Implemented `FrameworkDispatcher` and hooked the sound system into it. As a result, XAudio is always initialized on game main thread and sound functions are available also without using `Game`.

Some issues:
- The OpenAL changes need to be replicated in the SDL branch.
- Thread safety? Unit test indicates that XNA allows calling `Update()` from a separate thread, but I haven't figured out yet if it does some dispatching to the UI thread. [This MSDN page](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/microsoft.xna.framework.frameworkdispatcher.update.aspx) talks about using a `DispatcherTimer` to call `Update()`, so I've assumed that the responsibility is on the caller.
- Only tested on Windows desktop, and didn't have any game at hand to test this with.

data.title: SwapChainRenderTarget for UWP
data.body:
MonoGame already has a SwapChainRenderTarget class for Windows (desktop) and DirectX. We have extended this class to support UWP (Windows Universal) as well. 

You can view our changes here: https://github.com/DigitalRune/MonoGame/commit/a156710abf5f7cff070aa59ef601db27f8b77f9d
This commit also adds a SwapChainRenderTarget.Resize method for desktop and UWP.

We use the SwapChainRenderTarget to render graphics into UWP [SwapChainPanel](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.controls.swapchainpanel) XAML controls in regular UWP apps, for example: [UwpInteropSample (screenshot)](https://www.digitalrune.com/Portals/0/Blog/Files/12/2013/6ac1140b-273a-4157-8c33-193387e41b6a.jpg)
So far I have tested this in 3 UWP projects.

Currently I do not have the time to create pull request, but if there are no objection to these modifications I can create a PR in the next weeks.

data.title: Allow disabling Content Pipeline tests
data.body:
First off, I'm not sure if this issue actually affects more people, but I've found myself doing these changes repeatedly. Feel free to close if this seems not worth the trouble.

I don't have the full XNA framework on my dev computer, since I'm not too keen on installing an old VS version just to get the bits. The unit tests run nicely against the XNA redistributable, save for those involving the Content Pipeline, which is only included in the full framework. The missing types cause a build failure. This PR adds support for using `NO_CONTENTPIPELINE` symbol to disable all Content Pipeline tests/utilities and get the test project building.

Also added missing license headers to the files I touched. Visual Studio changed indentation on a couple of lines, sorry for that.

data.title: [DesktopGL] Heavy Song volume fluctuation
data.body:
Hello,

First, I should note that I don't know if the problem comes from the `OggStreamer` / NVorbis, OpenAL, or my own code.

When playing `Song` for an extended time (from 5 to 10 minutes, and it doesn't matter if it is the same song or a queue of different ones), it happens very often that the `Song` playing volume changes by itself without any call to `MediaPlayer` in the last couple minutes, and it can go from plain 0 to 1.

This happens on all platforms, with OpenAL-Soft or Apple/Creative's one, and only affects `Song`, not `SoundEffect`.

Our game can be very `SoundEffect` intensive, and `Song` are cross-faded by code. At first I thought that I was putting to much pressure on the OpenAL command buffer, but even adding locks to have a max of 10 AL calls per second doesn't change anything, and the problem can happen in moments when absolutely no `SoundEffect` is playing for several seconds.

Any thoughts?
